guide.introduction: This project is an attempt at designing a simple toy based on the principle of a light sensitive oscillator. It produces sound and light that vary in frequency with the intensity of light falling on it.
guide.introduction_rendered:
This project is an attempt at designing a simple toy based on the principle of a light sensitive oscillator. It produces sound and light that vary in frequency with the intensity of light falling on it.

Relevant parts
  • 555 Timer IC (RadioShack #276-1723)
  • 4040 - 12 bit counter IC
  • On/off switch
  • LDR Light Sensor
  • 5mm Blue LED Radio Shack Part #210-2850
  • LED, Red
  • Beeper/Buzzer
  • BC 549 - transistor
  • Resistor, 10kΩ, 1/8W
  • Resistors, 1kΩ
  • 2.2 uF capacitor
  • 9V battery
Tools
  • Dremel tool with cuttigng, grinding, or routing bits
  • Soldering/desoldering tools

lines.text: Download schematic and PCB files in EAGLE format from here.
lines.text_raw: Download schematic and PCB files in EAGLE format from [https://github.com/electronut/screechy|here].

lines.text: The circuit works using a combination of an oscillator and a frequency divider. You can read an explanation here.
lines.text_raw: The circuit works using a combination of an oscillator and a frequency divider. You can read an explanation [http://electronut.in/projects/i-screechy-a-light-sensitive-oscillator-toy/|here].

lines.text: You can use a general-purpose PCB for this project. But it's much cleaner to use a custom PCB.
lines.text_raw: You can use a general-purpose PCB for this project. But it's much cleaner to use a custom PCB.

lines.text: You can easily make a PCB at home using the toner transfer technique described in this link.
lines.text_raw: You can easily make a PCB at home using the toner transfer technique described in [http://www.riccibitti.com/pcb/pcb.htm|this link].

lines.text: Using the above link as guide, print out the PCB design on photo paper on a laser printer, iron it on to the copper laminate, and once the toner sticks, etch it out with ferric chloride. You can then drill holes in the PCB using a 0.8 mm bit on a Dremel tool.
lines.text_raw: Using the above link as guide, print out the PCB design on photo paper on a laser printer, iron it on to the copper laminate, and once the toner sticks, etch it out with ferric chloride. You can then drill holes in the PCB using a 0.8 mm bit on a Dremel tool.

lines.text: A pencil drawing on the non-copper side of the PCB will help you place the components easily. There are 2 connections that need to routed over the board manually using wires. Connect a wire between the two points labeled "A", and another wire between the two points labeled "B".
lines.text_raw: A pencil drawing on the non-copper side of the PCB will help you place the components easily. There are 2 connections that need to routed over the board manually using wires. Connect a wire between the two points labeled "A", and another wire between the two points labeled "B".

lines.text: Solder the components on to the PCB.
lines.text_raw: Solder the components on to the PCB.

lines.text: Use a dremel or any other tool of choice to cut holes for the LEDs, LDR, and switch.
lines.text_raw: Use a dremel or any other tool of choice to cut holes for the LEDs, LDR, and switch.

lines.text: Solder wires to LEDs, LDR and switch, and fix them on to the enclosure before soldering the other end of the wires to the PCB. I did it in the opposite order first and had to cut the wires to fix it!
lines.text_raw: Solder wires to LEDs, LDR and switch, and fix them on to the enclosure before soldering the other end of the wires to the PCB. I did it in the opposite order first and had to cut the wires to fix it!

lines.text: Drill some holes in the cap to let the sound out.
lines.text_raw: Drill some holes in the cap to let the sound out.

lines.text: Insert the PCB and 9V battery into the bottle. Place a small sheet of plastic in between to protect the PCB's solder joints from shorting on the battery.
